definition: Cao Pi 曹丕, emperor of Wei 220-226

surname Wei/name of vassal state of Zhou dynasty from 661 BC in Shanxi, one of the Seven Hero Warring States/Wei state, founded by Cao Cao 曹操[Cao2 Cao1], one of the Three Kingdoms after the Han dynasty/the Wei dynasty 221-265/Wei prefecture and Wei county at different historical periods
tower over a palace gateway (old)
language/culture/writing/formal/literary/gentle/(old) classifier for coins/Kangxi radical 67
surname Wen
emperor
Cao Pi (187-226), second son of Cao Cao 曹操, king then emperor of Cao Wei 曹魏 from 220, ruled as Emperor Wen 魏文帝, also a noted calligrapher
Sima Yan (236-290), founding emperor of Jin dynasty 晋 after the Three Kingdoms period, reigned 265-290 as Emperor Wu of Jin 晉武帝
Emperor Xian of Han (181-234), the final Han emperor, set up by Dong Zhuo 董卓, reigned 189-220, forced to abdicate 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕
Song of the Southern dynasties 南朝宋 (420-479), with capital at Nanjing
to accept abdication
Jin Dynasty (265-420)
Sima Zhao (211-265), military general and statesman of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4]
Western Jin dynasty (265-316)
Emperor Xuan (91-48 BC) of the Former Han Dynasty, reigned 74-48 BC
Song of the Southern dynasties (420-479), with capital at Nanjing/also known as Liu Song 劉宋|刘宋
Cao Wei, the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms, established as a dynasty in 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕, son of Cao Cao, replaced by Jin dynasty in 265
Cao Zhi (192-232), son of Cao Cao 曹操, noted poet and calligrapher
Emperor Wu of Song (363-422), personal name Liu Yu 劉裕|刘裕[Liu2 Yu4], founder of Song of the Southern dynasties 劉宋|刘宋[Liu2 Song4], broke away from Eastern Jin in 420, reigned 420-422
first Sui emperor (541-604) Yang Jian (541-604), reigned 581-604
